title: Navigation rail
description: Navigation rails provide access to primary destinations in apps when using tablet and desktop screens.

contentChunks.htmlValue: There's one type of navigation rail in Material. This component works best on larger screens and can be swapped with a navigation bar on smaller screens.

contentChunks.footer: A navigation rail with four destinations and a FAB.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 4 destinations, 1 active, and FAB.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – Navigation railAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• The navigation rail puts high-priority destinations within reach on large screens
  • The rail should appear consistently on the same side of each screen in an app
  • The rail complements adaptive and responsive navigation patterns
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • States: The active destination can be indicated with a pill shape in a contrasting color

contentChunks.footer: An active indicator is used to highlight the active destination
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 4 destinations and contrasting color shape identifying the active state

contentChunks.footer: M2: The navigation rail uses icon color, weight, and fill to communicate which destination is active.
contentChunks.altText: M2 navigation rail with 1 colored and filled icon showing the active state and 3 inactive icons

contentChunks.footer: M3: The navigation rail uses a pill-shaped active indicator to communicate which destination is active.
contentChunks.altText: M3 navigation rail with 1 icon surrounded by a pill shape in contrasting color to show the active state

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

States
States are visual representations used to communicate the status of a component or interactive element. Learn more about interaction states.

contentChunks.footer: Navigation rail states: 1. Enabled (on active destination), 2. hovered (on active destination), 3. focused (on active destination), 4. pressed (on active destination), 5. enabled (on inactive destination), 6. hovered (on inactive destination), 7. focused (on inactive destination), 8. pressed (on inactive destination)
contentChunks.altText: 4 navigation rails illustrating enabled, hovered, focused, and pressed states

Configurations
Common arrangements of elements within a navigation rail.

contentChunks.footer:
1. With a hamburger menu
2. With a FAB

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Contents

Usage

contentChunks.footer: A navigation rail with five destinations and a FAB in a map app.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 5 destinations, 1 active icon, and FAB next to a map screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage

The rail is a side navigation component that displays three to seven app destinations and, optionally, a floating action button (FAB). Each destination is represented by an icon and label text.

The rail can serve as the sole navigation component on larger screen sizes, such as desktops and tablets.

When your product is used on small screens, the navigation rail should be swapped for a navigation bar. When your product is used on desktop screens, the navigation rail can be swapped for a navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: A navigation rail can display three to seven app destinations represented by an icon and label text, with an optional FAB. A rail can serve as the sole navigation component on larger screens.
contentChunks.altText: 3 app destinations, 1 active, and FAB in a navigation rail next to a map screen

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Navigation rails should be used for:

  • Top-level destinations that need to be accessible anywhere in an app
  • Three to seven main destinations in a product
  • Tablet or desktop layouts

Navigation rails shouldn’t be used for:

  • Small screen sizes
  • Single tasks, such as viewing a single email
  • Secondary navigation destinations

contentChunks.footer: Used for top-level destinations that need to be accessible anywhere in an app, navigation rails include 3 to 7 main destinations in tablet or desktop layouts.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 4 destinations, 1 active next to a photos screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Menu (optional)
3. Floating action button (optional)
4. Active indicator
5. Icon - active
6. Label text - active (optional)
7. Icon - inactive
8. Label text - inactive (optional)
9. Large badge
10. Large badge label (optional)
11. Small badge
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail diagram numbering 11 elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

The navigation rail is placed on the leading edge of the screen; on the left side for left-to-right languages, and on the right side for right-to-left languages.

contentChunks.footer: Based on the language being used, a navigation rail is set on a screen’s leading edge, left side for left-to-right languages, and right side for right-to-left languages.
contentChunks.altText: 2 navigation rails with 4 destinations, one placed on the left leading edge and the other on the right

contentChunks.htmlValue:
The navigation rail should always run vertically along the side of a layout. For horizontal navigation components or smaller screens, consider using a navigation bar.

For closely related sibling views under one parent, tabs in combination with the navigation rail can form a cohesive navigation structure.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t position the navigation rail container horizontally.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail container placed horizontally on screen in a photos app

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Navigation rail destinations can be aligned as a group to the top, bottom, or center of a layout. On tablets, bottom alignment can make destinations easier for a user to reach with their thumbs.

The menu and FAB should always be aligned to the top of the navigation rail.

contentChunks.footer: Left to right: Top-, center-, and bottom-aligned rail destination placement.
contentChunks.altText: 3 navigation rails illustrating top-aligned, center-aligned, and bottom-aligned destinations

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Menu (optional)

The navigation rail can also include a menu icon to open a navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: A navigation rail can also include an overflow menu.
contentChunks.altText: Icon for an overflow menu set above navigation rail

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Floating action button (FAB) (optional)

The rail provides a convenient container for anchoring the FAB to the top of a screen, placing the app’s key action above navigation destinations.

When nested within another component, such as the navigation rail, the FAB's resting elevation is at level 0.

contentChunks.footer: A top-aligned FAB in the navigation rail.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with FAB anchored at top of screen

contentChunks.footer: Do not place the FAB below rail destinations.
contentChunks.altText: FAB placed at bottom of navigation rail

contentChunks.htmlValue: The top of the rail can also be used for a logo.

contentChunks.footer: Use caution when placing logos in the rail where they might be confused with an action or destination.
contentChunks.altText: Logo placed at top of navigation rail with visual similarities to other destination icons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Active indicator

The active indicator is a background shape communicating which destination of the navigation rail is currently being displayed.

contentChunks.footer: Use the active indicator only for the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 4 destinations, 1 active indicator

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use the active indicator for more than one destination at a time.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 4 destinations, all with active indicators

contentChunks.htmlValue: Upon selection of a destination, the active indicator visually expands behind its icon. This transformation is limited to one axis during the shape expansion.

contentChunks.footer: Animate the shape expansion along one axis to preserve the sense of a flat, shared plane.
contentChunks.altText: Animated active indicator expands on one horizontal axis

contentChunks.footer: Don’t animate the shape expansion uniformly.
contentChunks.altText: Animated active indicator expands uniformly behind icon

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icons

Navigation rail destinations are always represented by icons that symbolize the content or the nature of a destination.

contentChunks.footer: Destinations are always represented by icons in the navigation rail.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 3 inactive icons, 1 active icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: Active and inactive icon colors should have sufficient contrast against the container.

contentChunks.footer: Use the primary or high emphasis on color for the active destination.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations, 1 active destination with a high-emphasis color indicator

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use more than two colors for destinations or low-contrast colors in the navigation rail. This will make distinguishing active items more difficult.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail with 2 different color destinations, 1 with low-contrast

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

Label text provides short, meaningful descriptions of navigation destinations and an alternative way for users to understand an icon’s meaning. 

Labels can either be persistent or can appear on active destinations only.

contentChunks.footer: Write succinct labels that describe a destination.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations with icons and label text labeled “All Files” “Recent” “Images” and “Library” with the “Recent” destination selected

contentChunks.htmlValue: Labels should be short enough to not be truncated. Additionally, the type scale should not be reduced to fit longer text labels.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t truncate or display an ellipsis in place of label text.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations, 1 active label with truncated label text

contentChunks.footer: Don’t reduce the type size to fit more characters into a destination label.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations, 1 active label with smaller label text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Avoid wrapping long labels when possible. If necessary, create a line break between words, or hyphenate longer words.

contentChunks.footer: Break up longer phrases into two text lines if necessary.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations with 1 active label illustrating a line break between label text “All” and “Images”

contentChunks.htmlValue: If all icons in the navigation rail can have clear meaning to users, labels can be omitted.

contentChunks.footer: Ensure that icons are clear to users if labels are omitted.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail showing 4 destination icons

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Badges

Navigation rail icons can include badges on the upper right corner of the icon. Badges convey dynamic information about the associated destination, such as counts or status.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Small badge on a rail destination
2. Large badge with a number
3. Large badge with a maximum character count
contentChunks.altText: 4 navigation rail icons with various upper right corner badges

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Divider (optional)

A vertical divider can help separate the rail from app content. The divider should be positioned on the edge of the rail container that’s adjacent to the app’s content area.

contentChunks.footer: A divider can make the navigation rail container distinct from other on-screen content.
contentChunks.altText: Vertical divider separates navigation rail from content

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

With a navigation drawer

The rail provides access to three to seven top-level destinations. A modal navigation drawer, opened by selecting the menu icon, can work with the rail by displaying additional secondary destinations or actions.

contentChunks.footer: Pair the rail with a modal navigation drawer when there are secondary destinations or actions that don’t belong in the rail.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail transitions to modal navigation drawer

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use a navigation rail and bottom navigation on the same screen.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail on left edge, navigation bar on bottom edge of same screen

contentChunks.footer: Do not pair the rail with a permanent or persistent navigation drawer.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail placed on screen next to permanent navigation drawer

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout

When moving from a large screen to a small screen, a navigation rail can transform into a navigation bar, providing the same quick access in a configuration that’s easier to use on smaller displays. However, the navigation rail and navigation bar should never be used simultaneously.

contentChunks.footer: Left: On smaller devices, use a navigation bar. Right: On larger displays, use a navigation rail instead.
contentChunks.altText: Left side featuring smaller device using navigation bar, right side showing larger display using navigation rail

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Density

For dense layouts, the default container width can be reduced and label text omitted.

contentChunks.footer: The navigation rail at default width.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations, 1 active with icon and label text

contentChunks.footer: In denser layouts, the rail width can be reduced and label text omitted.
contentChunks.altText: 4 destinations, 1 active icon

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Scrolling

Destinations in the navigation rail should remain visible when scrolling vertically.

contentChunks.footer: Rail destinations remain fixed while on-screen content scrolls vertically.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail remains fixed as on-screen content for scrolls vertically in a photo app

contentChunks.htmlValue: If a layout scrolls horizontally, the rail can scroll off-screen or remain fixed. To distinguish that content is scrolling underneath the rail, use a divider or add elevation to the rail.

contentChunks.footer: A divider creates visual distinction between the rail and horizontally scrolling content.
contentChunks.altText: Navigation rail divided from horizontally scrolling content in photo all

contentChunks.footer: Elevating the rail to level 1 creates visual distinction between the rail and horizontally scrolling content.
contentChunks.altText: Elevated navigation rail is distinct from horizontally scrolling content

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection

When a destination is tapped, the destination screen uses a top level transition pattern. In addition, the icon becomes filled and the active indicator expands from the center of the icon.

contentChunks.footer: Tapping a destination uses a top level transition pattern.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Selection

When a destination is tapped, several transitions occur:

  • A touch ripple appears
  • The outgoing icon color changes from a brand color to grey
  • The outgoing icon moves down to align with the deactivated tabs, and then the label fades out
  • The incoming icon color changes from grey to a brand color
  • The incoming icon moves up, and the incoming label fades in

contentChunks.footer: Tapping a destination changes the outgoing icon color to grey, aligns the icon with deactivated tabs, allowing for the incoming icon to move up and change to a brand color.
contentChunks.altText: A tapped destination transitions from inactive to active

contentChunks.htmlValue: Use cases

Users should be able to: 

  • Navigate between navigation destinations with assistive technology
  • Select a particular navigation destination from a set
  • Get appropriate feedback based on input type documented under Interaction & style
Interaction & style

Touch

  • When a navigation item is tapped, the active indicator appears in place, providing feedback that it is selected 
  • A touch ripple passes through the indicator
  • The icon switches from outlined to filled
  • The icon changes color, becoming darker

Cursor

  • When hovered, the hover state appears providing a visual cue that the destination is interactive
  • When clicked (in both active and inactive states), a ripple passes through the active indicator
  • The icon switches from outlined to filled
    The icon changes color, becoming darker

contentChunks.footer: Touch: Tap
Cursor: Hover, Click

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Initial focus

Initial focus lands directly on the first navigation item, since that is the first interactive element of the component.

contentChunks.footer: 1. First tab on first item, 2. second tab on second item
1. First tab on first item, 2. space/enter on same item

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Visual indicators

Icons give the dominant cue of the navigation state. Use a filled icon for the selected destination to contrast with outlined icons for the non-selected destinations.

contentChunks.footer: Use a filled icon variant on the selected navigation item to differentiate from inactive navigation items.
Avoid using the same unfilled icon style for both selected and unselected items because it lacks important visual feedback cue.
When selected, a icon fills, darkens, and is given an active indicator.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Keyboard navigation

KeysActions
Tab
Focus lands on the first navigation destination 
Space / Enter
Selects the focused navigation destination

Labeling elements

The accessibility label for a navigation item is typically the same as the adjacent text label.

If the UI text is correctly linked to the switch, assistive tech (such as a screenreader) will read the UI text followed by the component’s role.

For Android Views, the role is not announced.

contentChunks.footer: A navigation bar’s accessibility label can incorporate its adjacent UI text.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Some accessibility labels require more descriptive text, particularly when the visible UI text is ambiguous. For example, a navigation item visibly labeled “Photo album” would benefit from additional information in its accessibility label to clarify the destinations intent.

For Android Views, a more descriptive accessibility label is not available.

contentChunks.footer: While the visible label text reads “Recents,” the accessibility label for this switch clarifies its function: “Recent images.”
